    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    The Chairman: Estimates of Expenditure of Singapore for the financial year 1st April 1970, to 31st March 1971, contained in Paper Cmd. 4 of 1970. For the convenience of hon. Members, I intend taking the total for each head of expenditure as it appears in the last column of the Abstract of Estimated Expenditure on pages 55 and 56 of the Paper.

    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Head 0106 -

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

Column: 670



    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0106 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2009.

    Sir, may I quote from page 22 of the Memorandum on the Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure of Singapore for the financial year 1st April, 1970, to 31st March, 1971 (Misc. 1 of 1970):

    'Decrease of $170,000 in O.C.A.R. is mainly due to a smaller provision being required for Bursaries and Other Assistance for Students of Higher Institutions based on past experience and a reduction in the number of President's Scholarships in view of the prestigious nature of these scholarships.'

    Sir, the President's scholarships for the year 1970-71 are being provided with a sum of $42,000 as against that of $124,370 for the period 1969-70, that is, a period of 15 months. In other words, no less than $82,000 has been lopped off. This is a drastic cut. I well know, Sir, that such scholarships are few in number and that, in most cases, the recipients win other awards. Therefore, three questions come to my mind. First, will the Prime Minister indicate the number of such holders who have graduated from their courses of study since the inception of the President's scholarships and in which areas they are

Column: 671

now serving? Secondly, whilst I agree that such top honours are not easy to gain, I am wondering whether this further cut will not dampen the keenness in competition of the aspirants, in view of a further reduction in the number of awards this year, as was so stated. Sir, no one doubts that this is a highly covetous award which many of our students are aiming to get. Thirdly, Sir, will the Prime Minister indicate the number of awards made last year as against the possible number this year?

    Sir, I beg to move.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, we had occasion to discuss this same matter in the 1968 budget session. The Member for Punggol knows that the standards required for the President's scholarships have been set very high. Awards are made to those with exceptional academic performance and extra-curricular activities. The numbers awarded were nine in 1966, seven in 1967, six in 1968 and four in 1969. The awards for 1970 are being considered at present. I cannot anticipate how many will finally be considered worthy of becoming President's scholars.

    However, since 1967 Merit scholarships have been awarded to those who have done well, but did not satisfy the high standards required of President's scholars. Twelve of these were awarded in 1967, 13 in 1968 and seven in 1969. Of the 26 President's scholars to date, eight have completed their studies. Two were taken into the Administrative Service, one to the Economic Development Board. The others are being interviewed for appointment.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, whilst going through the 1967 debate on the Estimates of Expenditure for 1968, in Vol. 26, from col. 632 (at the bottom) to col. 636, I notice that one point brought out was that the President's scholar, in addition to his winning the President's scholarship, will go on to win other scholarships as well and, as a result, he will get what is termed a "scholarship allowance" and not the full

Column: 672

award. My question is this. Will not the full award of the scholarship enhance the prestige of the recipient rather than just a scholarship allowance? If that is the case, I think this $42,000 will go a much longer way.

    The Prime Minister: With respect for the Member for Punggol, I believe that if scholarship is to be nurtured and encouraged, then too much money to young students may not necessarily bring about the best results. Last year, of the four who were President's scholars, three won other scholarships. So they were given a token sum of $500 per annum, in addition to their other scholarships. The year before, in 1968, of the six President's scholars, five won other scholarships. So each was given $500 per annum special allowance in recognition of their status as President's scholars.

    I am sure that the scholarships awarded are adequate for scholastic, social and other legitimate pursuits of our students. Giving them an unnecessarily extravagant sum of money will not improve the quality either of their studies, or their later performance in life.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: In that case, I thank the Prime Minister for his answer and I beg leave to withdraw my amendment. Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The Chairman: Mr Ng, you have one minute before "guillotine" time.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0106 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of subhead 2010.

    In moving this amendment, I have just one simple question. I wish to seek clarification from the Prime Minister as to what "unallocated awards" are.

    The Prime Minister: Unallocated awards provide for unforeseen training requirements of high priority which arise as a result of changing circumstances, or sudden requirements which cannot be

Column: 673

met from the regular bilateral or multilateral technical assistance schemes. The provision is utilised mainly for the awards, about 10 to 15 per year, for higher studies both in foreign and local institutions of higher learning. They meet the costs of passages, fees and expenses, and other relevant and necessary ad hoc expenditure.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Head 0107 -

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0107 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2001.

    Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to underline the importance of ensuring that drivers of Government vehicles take every care to exercise their responsibility on the road. I crave your indulgence by referring to a point which I think is relevant and which was made by the Minister for Finance in his Budget statement. He said that qualitative improvements have taken place in our society, that there is more social discipline and that parvenu values are giving way to more positive group values. I agree generally with this statement. But I would like to state it as my opinion that our highways and by-ways may be the last bastion of these parvenu values, where everybody thinks of himself and apparently the devil takes the hindmost. I suggest that we make every effort to ensure that Government vehicles set an example of social discipline on the road - an example which I find more honoured in the breach than

Column: 674

in the observance. There can be many ways and I leave it to the officers concerned to ensure this, but I think that every attempt should be made to get Government drivers to set an example of discipline on the public roads.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, traffic conditions are getting worse in Singapore. This provision looks after damage to private vehicles caused by Government vehicles. As the Member for Katong will be interested in the figures for last year, the Government paid a sum of $49,739 as compensation for damage caused by the 607 Government vehicles which were involved in accidents. But these vehicles are knocked, too, and the Government recovered as compensation for damages caused to Government vehicles a total sum of $23,375.

    The Member can rest assured that circulars are sent out to Government departments to make sure that drivers take care and follow road regulations. Where an accident occurs as a result of the negligence of the driver employed by the Government, and if the Attorney-General thinks that a prosecution should be brought, it is brought. On the other hand, the facts may not warrant a prosecution but may warrant disciplinary action to be taken against drivers of Government vehicles. In that case, disciplinary action is taken. But I would agree with the Member that drivers of Government vehicles should set the example in Singapore.

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, I thank the Minister for his answer and I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $720,620 for Head 0107 ordered to stand part of the Estimates.

    The Chairman: Amendment (1), Madam Chan is not present. Mr Ang Nam Piau, amendment (2).

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0301 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1101.

    Sir, the present Government came to power in 1959 and under the capable leadership of the People's Action Party, the administration is efficient, honest and clean and has won the acclaim of people from all over the world. If we compare our country with the other countries in South-east Asia, we can say that the administration in Singapore is the most efficient. Sir, this good reputation should be maintained at all costs and it should not be spoilt by certain officers who are arrogant and proud.

    I have received complaints from my constituents and I would like to cite an example. The Citizens' Consultative Committee in my constituency wrote a letter to the Director of the National Museum on 31st October, 1969, stating that there was a hornets' nest along Island Club Road and requesting him to clear the nest. There was no reply. They wrote another letter on 14th November, 1969, and still there was no reply. On 2nd December, 1969, they again wrote to him. A reply was received on 5th December, 1969, informing them that, owing to the shortage of staff, the National Museum was not able to take any action in this matter. Sir, hornets are dangerous insects - Order.

    The Chairman: Mr Ang, are you referring to subhead 1101?

    Mr Ang Nam Piau: Yes, Sir.

    The Chairman:Has the Director of National Museum anything to do with the destruction of hornets?

    Mr Ang Nam Piau: Yes. He replied to our letter but he took a long time to do so.

    The Chairman: All right, you may proceed.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau(In Mandarin): Sir, if there was an accident, what would be the consequences? This matter was raised by the Citizens' Consultative Committee in my constituency. And in spite of two reminders, we had to wait for two months before we received a reply from the Director of the National Museum. If an ordinary citizen were to write to a Government department, you can imagine what would be the result. Column: 677

Officer in the Museum? And is it necessary to have such a post in the Museum?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye : Mr Speaker, Sir, the Museum is visited very largely by school students and it is, therefore, essentially an educational institution. If the Museum is to serve its purpose usefully, it is necessary indeed that we should have one officer who will be able to organise tours on behalf of schools which carry out regular visits to the Museum. It is because of this reason that the post marked "Education Officer" has been created in the National Museum. This has been done on the advice of the National Museum Advisory Committee, of which the Member for Katong is the President. If the Member for Thomson wishes further information on this aspect, he can ask the Member for Katong.

    However, just to inform the House, the Education Officer is, as of this moment, seconded from the Ministry of Education. But it is our intention at some future date that this person should be part of the establishment of the Museum itself. The Member for Thomson may be interested to know that during the period 1st July to 31st December last year there were altogether 55 guided visits which represented 2,080 pupils and 194 teachers from 27 schools and the Teachers' Training College.

    Furthermore, the Museum organised eight practical and field courses for 117 teachers who were teaching nature science or biology. We have also plans to arrange for talks and demonstrations to science clubs in schools, and it is because of these extended and enlarged services of the Museum that we have come to the conclusion that a full-time Education Officer in the Museum will be very necessary.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0301 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 3005.

    Sir, in moving such a reduction, it is not my intention that we stop making continuous attempts to instil into the people the importance of science and technology. These two important aspects of the modern economic development of nations have been ignored for too long, during the colonial period and the early post-war period. To make up for the loss of time, the Government has wisely set up a Science Council recently, and in accordance with its policy of promoting the study and practice of science and technology, the Ministry of Science and Technology was set up in 1968. Regrettably, however, the functions of the Science Council, as well as those of the Ministry of Science and Technology, remain not quite well known to the man in the street.

    Whatever have been the achievements of the Ministry of Science and Technology in the past two years, there have been some at least that have not been well publicised. If the achievements have been modest, it is quite understandable because a relatively small allotment has been made to this Ministry in the past budget. The total allotment covering the 15 months was only $390,200, whereas this year it has been increased a bit. It now stands at $455,280.

    Sir, I strongly feel that if the Ministry is to be able, to quote the Minister for Finance, "to provide for effective economic and statistical evaluation as, well as to determine the needs of industry with greater precision", then the present staffing position, as outlined in the Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure of Singapore for the financial year 1st April, 1970, to 31st March, 1971, is far too inadequate.

    Sir, under subhead 3005 for this Ministry, I observe that $70,000 has been set aside, subject to Treasury sanction, for the employment of staff and $1

Column: 679

million under the Development Estimates for the establishment of the Popular Science Centre.

    Sir, I welcome the setting up of this centre, but with $1.7 million to start off for personal emoluments and the development of the Science Centre, I begin to wonder what kind of centre it will turn out to be and how it is going to achieve its desired objective of giving the citizens of Singapore a better understanding of what modern science is all about, although ultimately the building will cost $5.2 million. Sir, we know that even to set up a good laboratory in a secondary school costs much more than a million dollars.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Member for Telok Blangah for his very staunch support, and I certainly hope the Minister for Finance will take heed of what he has stated.

    I would like to explain to the House that the concept of the Science Centre is being revised. As Members will know, at the moment we have the National Museum, one part of which houses stuffed animals and the other part houses Chinese beads, coins, porcelain and similar antiques. We recently requested, through U.N.D.P., the assistance of an expert, Miss Weston, who was attached to the Science Museum in Kensington, to advise us on the setting up of the Popular Science Centre. She has submitted a report to the Government in which she has recommended a Science Centre, not quite similar to the one in London but one which will be able to demonstrate the application of science to technology, to be built in Singapore. We have recently been looking into this problem and have come to the conclusion that the proposed Popular Science Centre should be more than that. Since we are going to spend a substantial sum of money - $5 million and perhaps more - we ought to find, firstly, a suitable site, and, secondly, to make up our minds what the Popular Science Centre should be.

    The conclusion is that the Popular Science Centre should consist of two divisions. One division will show the application of science to technology, and the second division will show exhibits relating to the life sciences.

    Recently, we have another U.N.E.S.C.O. expert, Mr Gardner, who came to Singapore to advise us on how to modernise the National Museum. He has come to the conclusion that the animals we are stuffing in the National Museum are antiquated and out of date. Most museums these days devote only a very small corner of their building to taxonomy. So he has suggested that perhaps it would be more instructive if visitors to the Museum could be shown the origin of life evolution, the relation between man and his environment, that is the ecological aspects of living matter, and perhaps even school children will be able to relate how biology is integrated with environment.

    I shall be having a discussion over this problem with the Museum Advisory Committee and the Curator, and will put up a recommendation to the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Law and National Development. I hope that the former will give me more money and the latter will give me a site so that we can have a Popular Science Centre. Admittedly the present location of the National Museum constricts its development and it is impossible to put up any other building close by.

    Furthermore, the National Museum is now located in an area of land that is, very expensive indeed, and somehow I feel that it is not justifiable to go along and make a claim to very expensive land which can be used for more economical purposes. This, briefly, then is the thinking of the proposed Popular Science Centre. I hope that when the time comes for claims to be made on the Finance Minister and the Minister for Law and National Development, I will have the staunch support of the Member for Telok Blangah.

    Head 0401 -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0401 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*.

    (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Madam Chan Choy Siong).

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our economy has continued to progress very well in the last year. New factories are springing up all the time. New investments are coming in at a constant pace. This has enabled the various sectors in our economy to become prosperous. It has also created a large number of employment opportunities. The Ministry of Finance, of course, has done a great deal of good work. As a result of the prosperity in our economy, we have been able to overcome the adverse factors brought about by the impending withdrawal of the British forces.

    In the past, some people had certain worries and reservations. These have proved to be unfounded. The reason why we are enjoying our prosperity now is on account of two factors.

    Firstly, the Government has looked after all aspects of economic development very well. It has laid down plans and has provided excellent opportunities and favourable conditions for foreign capitalists to come here and invest.

    Secondly, our workers possess the aptitude and ability to work hard. In the interest of the country, they are willing to work hard. By doing this,

they help industries to prosper. Unfortunately, their wages are still rather low. That is why. I would ask the Minister for Finance to try to do something to raise their wages.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is another point I would like to make. Our external trade last year has increased considerably. Total trade last year has exceeded the sum of $10,984 million. It has increased by about $2,000 million over that of 1968. Although the figures show an improvement in our economy, generally from the ship-building industry, tourism and various other sectors of the economy, we cannot deny that the unfavourable balance of trade is a weakness. Therefore, I would like the Minister to find a solution to improve our balance of trade. For example, we should send more trade delegations to sell our goods overseas. We should not confine our trade only to entrepot trade but we should trade with many more countries on a mutually beneficial basis.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance has given a warning that we must not be complacent about our present situation. This is very true. We must always remain alert. Because of this, we must look for more ways and means of increasing our income. We must explore new territories to expand our economy further. For example, can we not look into the question of starting fishery and dairy industries in our small island? We could also include the growing of orchids, or perhaps the rearing of tropical fish.

    It seems that our tropical products are very popular and welcome in Europe. In the past few years the income from the export of these tropical products has been several million dollars. Although our country is small, our agricultural industry has managed to earn about $200 million per year. So long as we continue to work hard in this direction, we will he able to expand our agricultural industry.

    The Chairman: Madam Chan Choy Siong is not here.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, I agree with much of what the Member for Sembawang has said. I would like wages to rise as fast as possible, with the proviso, of course, that this will not have any adverse effect on investment. The way to do it is quite simple. First, whatever work is being done now by workers should be done more efficiently and with greater skill; to the extent that productivity increases, this will allow workers to get more pay for the same job. The second way in which we can increase wages will be to develop those industries where a high level of skill and a large number of skilled workers are required, such as in the engineering and shipbuilding industries. Both these ways of raising wages should be pursued vigorously.

    The Member is worried about unfavourable trade balances. I do not know whether he has been listening in regularly to Radio Peking! Because Radio Peking is also worried about our unfavourable trade balance. Within days of the publication of our annual statistics of imports and exports, which invariably show a deficit on the balance of trade - this can be anything from $500 million to $800 million - these figures are quoted by Radio Peking as evidence that we are being exploited, or heading for bankruptcy, or whatever it is. Actually this large unfavourable balance of trade does not worry me in the least. For the balance of trade, that is, the goods we import compared with the goods we export, is only one element in the total balance of payments. To offset this unfavourable trade balance, we have what people call invisible earnings, i.e., earnings from shipping, banking, insurance services, the tourist trade, and profits made on the entrepot trade. Taken as a whole, my recollection is that over the last four years we have had a favourable balance on current transactions, taking visible and invisible items together. However, we should try, of course, to increase

Column: 684

our exports, not so much to redress the unfavourable balance of trade, because I think this is of such an order of magnitude that it cannot be done, but because it would mean more income, more employment, and more prosperity for Singapore.

    Regarding the breeding of tropical fish and the growing of orchids, I am all with the Member for Sembawang provided he does not ask my Ministry to do anything about it. It is the responsibility of my colleague, the Minister for National Development. The Agricultural Research Station in Sembawang, which is in the Member's constituency, is doing a lot of work in breeding tropical fish. I believe they have discovered a way of making Japanese carp spawn in the tropics. This is the first time it is being done. In addition to orchids and tropical fish, I may say that we are doing quite a lucrative business in crocodiles. We rear crocodiles not only in farms in the countryside, but I am told in the city itself. However, lately I read in the newspapers that some crocodiles have escaped, and I hope this will not prove a menace to our citizens in future, This business of crocodiles, tropical fish and orchids has, as the Member said, a great prospect for growth.

I think the Minister will agree with me.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Mr Speaker. Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0401 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1031.

    Sir, the progress of modern industrialisation in the Republic deserves high admiration. Almost every aspect is being looked after, such as technical facilities, training, research, both in large- and medium-scale industries. Needless to say, with these modern industrial facilities production from these industries will be speeded up and a vast consumption at home and abroad is expected.
